title: Why I won’t fly Qantas again
text:
Des Houghton blog: CEOs on gay marriage, Bill Shorten on penalty rates Desmond Houghton, The Courier-Mail March 20, 2017 11:51am 
I OBJECT to that little Irish busybody Alan Joyce trying to dictate to Australians what they must do about gay marriage. 
The Qantas chief is entitled to his view, of course, but I’m not even sure he’s eligible to vote in this country. 
Joyce and other big companies including Telstra, Holden, Wesfarmers and the Commonwealth Bank are to be condemned for attempting to bully the Turnbull government to take action on “marriage equality” even though the thought of homosexual marriages is offensive to many. 
I have some news for you Mr Joyce: You can leap around like a leprechaun all you like but Australians have already voted for a plebiscite on same-sex marriage at the last federal election. 
Let’s leave it at that, pleeeeaasse. I hasten to add I have no ill will against the Irish. Indeed, my mother was a Donnelly from County Tyrone. 
Three years ago Blundering Bill Shorten also backed the plebiscite. 
If he had supported it in the Senate I suppose gay couples could be getting married now. 
What really annoys me is the hectoring tone and indignation of the gay marriage proponents. It seems they have little respect for other people’s views. 
I won’t fly Qantas again if I can avoid it. 
**** media_camera Labor and some unions have been accused of backing wage deals that would leave workers even worse off than proposed cuts to weekend penalty rates. File picture 
I HAVE been saying for some time now that Blundering Bill is a hypocrite. And I was right. 
Labor and the unions have been trying to block the proposed cuts to weekend penalty rates while at the same time backing wage deals that allow fast-food ­giants like McDonald’s and KFC to pay their staff less than the Fair Work Commission’s suggested new pay level . 
Malcolm Turnbull will today expose union-sanctioned enterprise bargaining agreements showing many workers at the ­nation’s large fast-food chains earn about $3 an hour less now than they would even under the Fair Work Commission’s lower Sunday penalty rates. 
Turnbull will also move to ban secret payments between businesses and unions of the kind revealed by the Royal Commission into Trade Unions involving Opposition Leader Bill Shorten’s former union, the Australian Workers’ Union, when the Labor leader was at the helm. 
Turnbull’s laws will involve maximum sentences of 10 years in jail and a $900,000 fine for individuals who infringe them, and a $4.5 million fine for corporations. 
The Heydon royal commission uncovered a raft of payments between employers and unions, which it called “corrupting benefits” designed to ensure companies favourable treatment from unions.
